instructions: Plan tests from cheap, high-yield to expensive, specialized. Start with history/physical; only request a test if its result can change management or meaningfully reduce diagnostic uncertainty. If you are already ≥70% confident about the top diagnosis, output DIAGNOSIS READY instead of requesting more tests. At most one test per turn. Avoid back-to-back imaging unless new information justifies it. You may override and escalate for red-flag features (e.g., focal neurological deficit, acute abdomen, hemodynamic instability).

labs_basic.description: Low-cost labs; broad screening and triage.

imaging_plain.description: Plain radiographs; first-line for many MSK and chest complaints.

imaging_ultrasound.description: Ultrasound; abdominal/RUQ/pelvic first-line and no radiation.

imaging_ct.description: CT; higher cost/radiation; use if US/X-ray non-diagnostic or red flags.

imaging_mri.description: MRI; highest cost; soft tissue/CNS detail; use when results will change management.

transitions.conditions: Use when test is likely to discriminate top diagnoses or change management; prefer labs_basic/microbiology; use imaging_plain/ultrasound only if strongly indicated by symptoms/exam.
Escalate if labs suggest a focal process or remain inconclusive and imaging is likely to clarify next step.
Escalate if X-Ray is non-diagnostic but imaging will change management; consider ultrasound before CT where applicable.
If ultrasound is non-diagnostic or discordant and CT is expected to change management.
Only when MRI detail will change management (e.g., neuro/soft tissue) or CT is non-diagnostic.
EKG±Troponin first; Echo if indicated; escalate to CT/MRI only for specific high-risk scenarios.
